user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_equal_quoted_bin_n:
```c
bool
MHD_str_equal_quoted_bin_n (const char *quoted,
                            size_t quoted_len,
                            const char *unquoted,
                            size_t unquoted_len)
{
  size_t i;
  size_t j;
  if (unquoted_len < quoted_len / 2)
    return false;

  j = 0;
  for (i = 0; quoted_len > i && unquoted_len > j; ++i, ++j)
  {
    if ('\\' == quoted[i])
    {
      i++; /* Advance to the next character */
      if (quoted_len == i)
        return false; /* No character after escaping backslash */
    }
    if (quoted[i] != unquoted[j])
      return false; /* Different characters */
  }
  if ((quoted_len != i) || (unquoted_len != j))
    return false; /* The strings have different length */

  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (quoted[i] != unquoted[j])
      return false; /* Different characters */
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The loop condition (i < quoted_len && j < unquoted_len) guarantees quoted[i] and unquoted[j] are in bounds at entry, and when a backslash is seen the code increments i and immediately checks if i == quoted_len and returns if so, preventing an out-of-bounds access. Also, this code does not call any <string.h> functions (so MISRA Rule 21.17, which targets those functions, is not applicable). A specific violation scenario would be if the check 'if (quoted_len == i) return false;' were removed (or the loop condition changed), allowing quoted[i] to be accessed when i == quoted_len.
